Index

George Orwell was born on June 25th, 1903, in Motihari, a northwestern Bihar state in Bengal, India. As he was the son of a British civil servant, Richard Walmesley Blair, Orwell spent his first days in India, where his father was stationed. However, at just a year old, his mother, Ida Mabel Limouzin, took him, as well as Majorie, his older sister, to go to the United Kingdom because their father had been appointed as an overseer of opium production for the British Empire in India. Eventually, they settled in a town called Henley-on-Thames.

✮ When and where was George Orwell born?

* To carry on his legacy, we will continue to refer to him by his pseudonym

George Orwell's real name was Eric Arthur Blair. He adopted the pen name 'George Orwell' in the 1930s when he began writing and for various different reasons.First off, he chose to use a pen name because he wanted to keep his writing separate from his work as a teacher because he felt as if his real name was too boring and characterless, alongside the fact that it reminded him of a prig in Vitorian boys’ story.Furthermore, he also created a pseudonym partly to avoid embarrassing his parents, partly as a hedge against failure.

✮ What was George Orwell's birth name? Why did he pick 'George Orwell' as his pen name?

Like mentioned previously, Orwell spent most of his childhood and adult life in England.

✮ Where did George Orwell spend his childhood?

George Orwell’s family belonged to the lower-upper-middle class. However, unfortunately, after Richard Blair's death in 1917, the family’s financial situation was not always stable and they struggled to maintain their social status.As time went on, their social status relentlessly decreased. With this being said, George Orell had to provide for his family and also support himself. Thus, in 1922, at the age of 19, and as a poor college student, he joined the Imperial Police. As a part of this organization, he lived and worked in Burma where he was responsible for the safety and security of over 200,000 people

✮ What was George Orwell and his family's financial state? What was their social class?

Like many other young boys in England at the time, Orwell was sent to a boarding school. In 1911, he went to St. Cyprian's School, a private preparatory school for boys in the coastal town of Eastbourne, where he got his first taste of England's class system.On a partial scholarship, Orwell noticed that the school treated the wealthier students better than the poor ones. He wasn't popular amongst his peers. Fortunately, he found comfort from his difficult situation through books, such as works by Rudyard Kipling and H.G. Wells.While he did lack idividual personality, he made up for it by his prominent intelligence and intellectuality. Orwell won scholarships to Wellington College and Eton College, a prestigious boarding school in England, to continue his studies. and later at the University of Oxford. However, he did not complete his degree at Oxford as his family did not have the money to pay for a university education. Instead, he joined the Indian Imperial Police in Burma in 1922.

✮ Where did George Orwell study?

During his young adult life, Orwell lived in Paris for two years before returning, once more, to England where he continued living in his family home for five years.To clarify, George Orwell went to Paris for a handful of objectives.To begin with, he wanted to experience life in poverty, which is to say, live at a cheaper cost.Secondly, he wanted to learn the complex French language and improve his writing skills.Most of his stay was spent in abject poverty, actual hunger, and hunting for menial work. He wanted to see how the working class lived and write about his experiences.He spent several years in the 'City of Lights' working multiple low-paying jobs and living in horrid conditions.In fact, his very first novel, published in 1933, was inspired by his experience there. It's titled "Down and Out in Paris and London".

✮ Where did George Orwell live in the twenties?

*To learn more about his writing career, go to page 14 of this presentation

Orwell's first 'official' job was a police officer in Burma. He worked there for five years, from 1922 to 1927. After returning to England, he became a private tutor and eventually worked as a teacher at a private school in Hayes, Middlesex. However, he found it to be unfulfilling, and quite honestly, tedious. After a year, he finally quit and made the decision to devote his thoughts and time to writing. Moreover, his first career was as a writer when he published the book, previously mentioned, "Down and Out in Paris and London", in 1933.

✮ What was George Orwell's first job?

In the 1930s, George Orwell fought in the Spanish Civil War as a member of the Workers' Party of MarxistUnification (POUM), a- Trotskyist political party. Orwell's experiences during the war, includinghis near-fatal injury, had a profound impact on his political views and inspired much of his later writing.After being shot in the neck while fighting in Spain, Orwell was forced to flee the country and return to England, where he continued to write and publish works that were critical of totalitarianism, fascism, and political oppression. George Orwell's experiences during the Spanish Civil War had a profound impact on his political views and inspired much of his later writing. His time in Spain, where he fought as a member of the Workers' Party of Marxist Unification, exposed him to the brutality of war and the dangers of totalitarianism and political oppression. Orwell's near-fatal injury in Spain also had a lasting impact on his health, and he suffered from chronic pain and other health issues for the rest of his life.

✮ What war did George Orwell partake in in the thirties? What happened to him?

At the break of World War II, he was deemed unfit for military service because of poor physical health. This was due to numerous factors; he had suffered from bronchitis and other respiratory problems since childhood, and he also had a weak lung from a gunshot wound he received while fighting in the Spanish Civil War. Not to mention the fact that he was living in extreme poverty for many many years, so we can only imagine the horrid tolls this took on him as well. Nonetheless, he did join the Home Guard, a volunteer organization that was intended to serve as a secondary defense in the event of a Nazi invasion of Great Britain. Furthermore, Orwell also worked for the British Broadcasting Company, abbreviated to BBC, by supervising broadcasts to India, which were intended to act as a counter to Nazi propaganda.

✮ What did George Orwell do for the country during the Second World War?

George Orwell's political views were complex and greatly evolved over time.He was deeply committed to democratic socialism and believed in theimportance of individual freedom, social justice, and equality. Orwell was a fiercecritic of totalitarianism, fascism, and political oppression; he wrote extensivelyabout the dangers of these systems of government. Adding onto this, he wasalso critical of capitalism and believed that it could lead to social inequalityand exploitation.Overall, Orwell's political views were shaped by his experiences with war, poverty, and social injustice, and his commitment to democratic socialism and individual freedom remains a central theme in much of his writing.

✮ What were George Orwell's political views?

As his life progressed, Orwell found a career as a writer. It was around this time that he started to use his pen-name. The books he wrote were generally works of non-fiction. He typically described the living conditions of the poor or related them [the books] with his experiences of traveling in different parts of the world. He also wrote a large number of hard hitting political commentaries which appeared in newspapers and magazines. Additionally, he reviewed many books and became a notable influence on literary criticism.Furthemore, Orwell became best-known for two works of fiction. Animal Farm, published in 1945 and Nineteen Eighty-Four, published in 1949. They are both highly regarded works of fiction.

✮ What were George Orwell's most renowed books?

The Green Flag

The Communist Flag

Animal Farm

Animal Farm is an allegorical tale about a group of farm animals who overthrow their (human) farmer and establish a society where animals prevail and dominate. However, the pigs, who are the smartest animals on this very farm, become corrupt and begin to abuse their powerful authority. This book served as an allegory for Joseph Stalin's rise to power in the Soviet Union.

Nineteen Eighty-Four

Nineteen Eighty-Four is a dystopian tale set in a totalitarian society where the individuals are completely controlled by its government, more precisely by a mysterious figure known as Big Brother. He has complete control over every aspect of the citizens’ lives, whether it’s decisions and beliefs, or even routines and clothing.This novel is a warning about the brutal and horrendous dangers of totalitarianism and the importance of individual freedom. It is viewed by many as ‘one of the most influential novels of the twentieth century’.

"If liberty means anything at all, it means the right to tell people what they do not want to hear."

"Threats to freedom of speech, writing and action, though often trivial in isolation, are cumulative in their effect and, unless checked, lead to a general disrespect for the rights of the citizen."

"However much you deny the truth, the truth goes on existing."

"Some ideas are so stupid that only intellectuals believe them."

"The past was erased, the erasure was forgotten, the lie became the truth."

"It's frightful that people who are so ignorant should have so much influence."

"Real power is achieved when the ruling class controls the material essentials of life, granting and withholding them from the masses as if they were privileges."

"Free speech is my right to say what you don't want to hear."

"The people will believe what the media tells them they believe."

"The further a society drifts from truth the more it will hate those who speak it."

✮ What were some quotations that George Orwell stated?

George Orwell died at the age of 46, on January 21st, 1950.He had long suffered from poor physical health and had been diagnosed with tuberculosis just a few years earlier, in 1947. His death was caused by a burst artery in his lung. He was buried with a simple headstone, which bears the name ‘Eric Arthur Blair’. It, however, doesn’t make any reference to the name ‘George Orwell’.

✮ When did George Orwell die and how?

George Orwell's legacy to literature and society is highly significant.In our modern day and age, Orwell is remembered as one of the world's greatest authors. His influence reached far beyond the world of literature. Terms that Orwell created such as ‘doublethink’, ‘thought police’, and ‘Big Brother’ are all used in popular culture today. Additionally, he was the first modern author to use the phrase ‘Cold War’. Adding onto this, even his name has entered the common language. To elaborate, when someone is attempting to describe an oppressive overreaching government, the individual might use the term ‘Orwellian’. Not to mention, the important requirement in highschool classrooms, all around the world, to read George Orwell's influential books.Furthermore, his works have had a profound impact on the way we think about politics, language, and truth. His critiques of totalitarianism and political oppression have inspired generations of writers and activists, and his ideas about the importance of clear and honest communication continue to be relevant today. Orwell's work has also been influential in the field of journalism, and his essays and reporting are known for their clarity and objectivity. Overall, Orwell's legacy to literature in society is one of social and political commentary, honesty, and a commitment to truth and justice.His impact on society and literature will surely continue to be felt for several years to come.
